headline: Easy Boston Brown Bread Recipe
description: Moist and sweet with molasses, this steamed quick bread is easier than you think.
name: Easy Boston Brown Bread Recipe
keywords: boston brown bread, boston brown bread recipe, boston brown bread in a can
recipeIngredient: 2/3 cup regular or blackstrap molasses (see note)
Cream cheese to serve on the side

recipeInstructions.text: Coat three 14.5- to 15-ounce cans (about 4 inches tall and 2 3/4 inches wide) with cooking spray and place a round piece of parchment paper in the bottom of each can. Place a trivet or steamer insert into the bottom of a tall stockpot, fill with water to reach 1 1/2 inches above the trivet. Cover with a tight-fitting lid and bring to a simmer over medium-high.

In a medium bowl, whisk together rye flour, raisins, cornmeal, baking soda, and salt until evenly combined. Whisk in buttermilk and molasses until just combined. Divide batter evenly between prepared cans (about 1 cup/200g batter per can; the batter should fill the cans no more than 2/3 of the way full). Place a small square of foil over the top of each can to serve as a lid and secure with a heavy-duty rubber band or string.

Set cans on trivet in the pot of boiling water. The water should reach about halfway up the sides of the cans (if not, add additional hot water). Cover and return to a simmer over medium-high heat. Reduce heat to medium-low and gently simmer until bread is set and gently pulling away from sides of cans, 35 to 40 minutes. A skewer inserted into the center should come out with moist crumbs and a thermometer inserted into the center should register between 200°F and 205°F.

Remove cans from pot using tongs, set on a cooling rack, and remove foil lids. Let bread cool in cans slightly, 20 to 30 minutes. Remove bread from cans by turning each can upside down and tapping the bottom of the can with the heel of your palm. Let loaves cool completely on wire rack, about 1 hour. Serve plain or toasted with cream cheese, preferably the next day (the flavors meld and improve with this resting time).

review.reviewBody: Just made this recipe today. Used regular molasses. Very easy to make. Ate it with unsalted butter. Very delicious. New go to recipe.

All steaming recipes I’ve ever seen use a covered pot (for the water, that is). This recipe doesn’t say, but I’d go with a covered pot, as I can’t imagine much steaming occurring with all the steam escaping.

According to several sources I read, blackstrap molasses CANNOT be used one-to-one as a substitute for regular molasses! Regular molasses comes in regular and dark, but dark regular molasses is NOT the same as blackstrap. 

My sources said that blackstrap is stronger and saltier, and less sweet, so if you substitute with blackstrap, you should halve the amount and add up to the called for amount with corn syrup. (Basically, if the recipe calls for 1/2 cup molasses, you can use 1/4 cup blackstrap plus 1/4 cup corn syrup). And I would venture to say you could use honey instead of corn syrup.

Happy baking!

This is my ritual breakfast on black Friday while my wife is out shopping. Pan fried leftover brown bread topped with a slathering of left over home made cranberry sauce. Make sure to cut the bread into half inch rounds, you want them thick enough to crisp on the outside but stay soft on the inside.
The cans that Muir Glenn packs its tomatoes in are chemical-free.
